exercises.question: Last summer, we ___ to a beautiful beach in Spain.
exercises.example_sentence: Last summer, we went to a beautiful beach in Spain.

options: I did not liked the movie.
exercises.example_sentence: I didn't like the movie because it was too long.

exercises.example_sentence: I bought an apple and ate it.

exercises.example_sentence: They traveled to London.

exercises.question: My brother ___ a new car two days ago.
exercises.example_sentence: My brother bought a new car two days ago.

exercises.question: Transform to a question: 'They saw a famous actor.'
options: Did they see a famous actor?
Do they saw a famous actor?
Did they saw a famous actor?
exercises.answer: Did they see a famous actor?
exercises.example_sentence: Did they see a famous actor at the party?

exercises.example_sentence: We had dinner at eight.

exercises.example_sentence: He wrote a letter and spoke to me.

exercises.example_sentence: I finished my homework.

exercises.question: We ___ a delicious dinner at a French restaurant last night.
exercises.example_sentence: We ate a delicious dinner at a French restaurant last night.

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct?
options: She didn't went to the party.
She didn't go to the party.
She doesn't went to the party.
exercises.answer: She didn't go to the party.
exercises.example_sentence: She didn't go to the party because she was tired.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: When did you visit London?

exercises.example_sentence: I saw the movie and took some notes.

exercises.answer: I walked to the park yesterday.
exercises.example_sentence: I walked to the park yesterday.

exercises.question: They ___ a lot of photos during their trip to Italy.
exercises.example_sentence: They took a lot of photos during their trip to Italy.

exercises.question: Change to a question: 'He bought a new phone.'
options: Did he buy a new phone?
Did he bought a new phone?
Does he buy a new phone?
exercises.answer: Did he buy a new phone?
exercises.example_sentence: Did he buy a new phone last week?

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: he did not finish his homework
exercises.example_sentence: He did not finish his homework.

exercises.question: Match the time expressions.
exercises.example_sentence: I worked last week, but I am free today.

exercises.question: Repeat: We lived in Spain two years ago.
exercises.answer: We lived in Spain two years ago.
exercises.example_sentence: We lived in Spain two years ago.

exercises.question: Sarah ___ got a new laptop for her university studies.
exercises.example_sentence: Sarah has got a new laptop for her university studies.

exercises.question: Which sentence describes a comparison correctly?
options: The train is more fast than the bus.
The train is faster than the bus.
The train is more faster than the bus.
exercises.answer: The train is faster than the bus.
exercises.example_sentence: The train is faster than the bus when traveling to the city.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: this phone is more expensive than that
exercises.example_sentence: This phone is more expensive than that one.

exercises.question: Match the adjective to its comparative form.
exercises.example_sentence: This cake is better than the one I made yesterday.

exercises.question: Repeat: My house is smaller than yours.
exercises.answer: My house is smaller than yours.
exercises.example_sentence: My house is smaller than yours, but it is very cozy.

exercises.question: I ___ got any brothers or sisters; I am an only child.
exercises.example_sentence: I haven't got any brothers or sisters; I am an only child.

exercises.question: Choose the correct question form:
exercises.example_sentence: Have you got a map of the city center?

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: Today is colder than yesterday.

exercises.question: Match the opposites.
exercises.example_sentence: The bus is cheaper than the taxi.

exercises.question: Repeat: This book is more interesting.
exercises.example_sentence: This book is more interesting than the last one.

exercises.question: Please be quiet because the baby ___ in the next room.
exercises.example_sentence: Please be quiet because the baby is sleeping in the next room.

exercises.question: Transform to negative: 'We are watching a movie.'
options: We are not watching a movie.
We not are watching a movie.
exercises.answer: We are not watching a movie.
exercises.example_sentence: We are not watching a movie; we are reading books.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: we are having lunch at one
exercises.example_sentence: We are having lunch at one.

exercises.question: Match the subject to the correct 'be' verb.
exercises.example_sentence: I am working today, and they are working too.

exercises.question: Repeat: She is studying for her exam.
exercises.answer: She is studying for her exam.
exercises.example_sentence: She is studying for her exam in the library.

exercises.question: Look! The children ___ in the garden right now.
exercises.example_sentence: Look! The children are playing in the garden right now.

exercises.question: Which sentence is a correct question?
options: Are you coming to the party?
You are coming to the party?
Do you coming to the party?
exercises.answer: Are you coming to the party?
exercises.example_sentence: Are you coming to the party tonight?

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: What is he cooking for dinner?

exercises.question: Match the present simple to present continuous.
exercises.example_sentence: He usually drives, but today he is walking.

exercises.question: Repeat: What are you doing this weekend?
exercises.answer: What are you doing this weekend?
exercises.example_sentence: What are you doing this weekend? Do you want to meet?

exercises.question: Next weekend, I ___ visit my grandparents in the countryside.
exercises.example_sentence: Next weekend, I am going to visit my grandparents in the countryside.

exercises.question: Transform to negative: 'I am going to travel next month.'
options: I am not going to travel next month.
I don't going to travel next month.
I not going to travel next month.
exercises.answer: I am not going to travel next month.
exercises.example_sentence: I am not going to travel next month because I need to save money.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: what are you going to watch ?
exercises.example_sentence: What are you going to watch on TV tonight?

exercises.question: Match the subject to the correct future form.
exercises.example_sentence: I am going to cook pasta while he is going to cook rice.

exercises.question: Repeat: We are going to have a party on Saturday.
exercises.answer: We are going to have a party on Saturday.
exercises.example_sentence: We are going to have a party on Saturday for his birthday.

exercises.question: Look at those dark clouds! It ___ rain very soon.
exercises.example_sentence: Look at those dark clouds! It is going to rain very soon.

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct?
options: She is going to buy a new car.
She going to buy a new car.
She is go to buy a new car.
exercises.answer: She is going to buy a new car.
exercises.example_sentence: She is going to buy a new car because her old one is broken.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: he is not going to work tomorrow
exercises.example_sentence: He is not going to work tomorrow because it's a holiday.

exercises.example_sentence: Next year I am going to Spain, but last year I went to Italy.

exercises.question: Repeat: Are you going to join us for dinner?
exercises.answer: Are you going to join us for dinner?
exercises.example_sentence: Are you going to join us for dinner tonight?

exercises.question: Yesterday, I ___ a very interesting movie.
exercises.example_sentence: Yesterday, I watched a very interesting movie with my friends.

options: She is going to the park.
exercises.example_sentence: She went to the park two hours ago.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: they did not visit us last week
exercises.example_sentence: They did not visit us last week because they were busy.

exercises.question: Match the present verb to its past form.
exercises.example_sentence: I ate a sandwich and drank some water.

exercises.question: Repeat: We traveled to London last summer.
exercises.answer: We traveled to London last summer.
exercises.example_sentence: We traveled to London last summer by plane.

exercises.question: He ___ his homework before dinner.
exercises.example_sentence: He finished his homework before dinner yesterday.

exercises.question: Pick the correct question:
exercises.example_sentence: Did you see the news on TV this morning?

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: What did you buy yesterday at the mall?

exercises.question: Match the verb to the category.
exercises.example_sentence: I played football, but then I went home.

exercises.question: Repeat: I didn't know the answer.
exercises.example_sentence: I didn't know the answer to the teacher's question.

exercises.question: ___ you go to the beach last Sunday?
exercises.hint: Use the auxiliary for past questions.
exercises.example_sentence: Did you go to the beach last Sunday with your family?

exercises.question: Select the correct negative sentence:
exercises.example_sentence: She didn't like the food at the new restaurant.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: did he buy a new car ?
exercises.example_sentence: Did he buy a new car last month?

exercises.question: Match the sentence to its type.
exercises.example_sentence: I worked yesterday, but did you work?

exercises.question: Repeat: They didn't see us at the station.
exercises.answer: They didn't see us at the station.
exercises.example_sentence: They didn't see us at the station this morning.

exercises.question: We ___ have enough time to finish.
exercises.example_sentence: We didn't have enough time to finish the exam.

exercises.question: Choose the correct question:
exercises.example_sentence: Where did you go for your holidays?

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: Did she arrive home late last night?

exercises.question: Match the question to the correct short answer.
exercises.example_sentence: Did you like it? Yes, I did.

exercises.question: Repeat: Why did you call me so late?
exercises.answer: Why did you call me so late?
exercises.example_sentence: Why did you call me so late last night?

exercises.question: When I was five years old, I ___ ride a bike.
exercises.example_sentence: When I was five years old, I couldn't ride a bike, but I can now.

exercises.question: Which sentence is a polite request?
options: Could you help me with this bag?
Can you help me with this bag?
You could help me with this bag.
exercises.answer: Could you help me with this bag?
exercises.example_sentence: Could you help me with this bag? It is very heavy.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: she can speak English very well
exercises.example_sentence: She can speak English very well because she lives in London.

exercises.question: Match the ability to the correct person.
exercises.example_sentence: Birds can fly high in the sky, while fish can swim fast.

exercises.question: Repeat: I can play the guitar.
exercises.example_sentence: I can play the guitar and the piano.

exercises.question: ___ you speak Spanish when you lived in Madrid?
exercises.example_sentence: Could you speak Spanish when you lived in Madrid?

exercises.question: Change to negative: 'He can swim.'
exercises.example_sentence: He cannot swim, so he stays near the beach.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: Could I open the window? It is hot here.

exercises.question: Match the time to the modal verb.
exercises.example_sentence: I couldn't cook before, but I can now.

exercises.question: Repeat: Could you repeat that, please?
exercises.example_sentence: Could you repeat that, please? I didn't hear you.

exercises.question: I wanted to go for a walk, ___ it started to rain heavily.
exercises.example_sentence: I wanted to go for a walk, but it started to rain heavily.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses 'because' correctly?
options: He stayed home because he was sick.
He stayed home but he was sick.
He stayed home or he was sick.
exercises.answer: He stayed home because he was sick.
exercises.example_sentence: He stayed home because he was sick and needed rest.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: She likes tea and coffee in the morning.

exercises.question: Match the beginning to the correct ending.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm tired because I worked late last night.

exercises.question: Repeat: Do you prefer tea or coffee?
exercises.answer: Do you prefer tea or coffee?
exercises.example_sentence: Do you prefer tea or coffee for breakfast?

exercises.question: He studied very hard, ___ he passed the exam easily.
exercises.example_sentence: He studied very hard, and he passed the exam easily.

exercises.question: Choose the correct option for a choice:
options: We can go to the cinema or the park.
We can go to the cinema because the park.
We can go to the cinema but the park.
exercises.answer: We can go to the cinema or the park.
exercises.example_sentence: We can go to the cinema or the park this afternoon.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: she is happy because it is sunny
exercises.example_sentence: She is happy because it is sunny today.

exercises.question: Match the conjunction to its function.
exercises.example_sentence: I like fruit but I don't like vegetables.

exercises.question: Repeat: I am late because the bus was slow.
exercises.answer: I am late because the bus was slow.
exercises.example_sentence: I am late because the bus was slow this morning.

exercises.question: I don't have ___ money in my wallet today.
exercises.example_sentence: I don't have much money in my wallet today.

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct for a large quantity?
options: There are a lot of people at the station.
There are much people at the station.
There is many people at the station.
exercises.answer: There are a lot of people at the station.
exercises.example_sentence: There are a lot of people at the station this morning.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: he has many friends in London
exercises.example_sentence: He has many friends in London.

exercises.question: Match the quantifier to the noun type.

exercises.question: Repeat: There is a little milk in the fridge.
exercises.answer: There is a little milk in the fridge.
exercises.example_sentence: There is a little milk in the fridge for your tea.

exercises.question: How ___ brothers and sisters do you have?
exercises.example_sentence: How many brothers and sisters do you have?

exercises.question: Choose the correct question for time:
options: How much time do we have?
How many time do we have?
How a lot of time do we have?
exercises.answer: How much time do we have?
exercises.example_sentence: How much time do we have before the train leaves?

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: we have only a few minutes
exercises.example_sentence: We have only a few minutes left.

exercises.question: Match the quantifier to the meaning.
exercises.example_sentence: I have a lot of books, but only a few pens.

exercises.question: Repeat: I eat a lot of fruit.
exercises.answer: I eat a lot of fruit.
exercises.example_sentence: I eat a lot of fruit every day.

exercises.question: My birthday is ___ June 15th.
exercises.example_sentence: My birthday is on June 15th, and I am having a party.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: I start work at nine o'clock
exercises.example_sentence: I start work at nine o'clock every morning.

exercises.question: Match the time expression to the preposition.

exercises.question: Repeat: See you on Monday morning.
exercises.example_sentence: See you on Monday morning at the office.

exercises.question: We usually go to the beach ___ summer.
exercises.example_sentence: We usually go to the beach in summer because it's hot.

exercises.question: Choose the correct preposition of place:
options: The keys are on the table.
The keys are in the table.
The keys are at the table.
exercises.answer: The keys are on the table.
exercises.example_sentence: The keys are on the table near the door.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: let's meet at the bus stop
exercises.example_sentence: Let's meet at the bus stop at 5 PM.

exercises.question: Match the location to the preposition.
exercises.example_sentence: He is in France, sitting on the floor.

exercises.question: Repeat: The meeting is at noon.
exercises.example_sentence: The meeting is at noon in the conference room.

exercises.question: I ___ drink coffee in the morning because I don't like the taste.
exercises.example_sentence: I never drink coffee in the morning because I don't like the taste.

exercises.question: Which sentence has the correct word order?
options: She usually is late for work.
She is usually late for work.
Usually she late is for work.
exercises.answer: She is usually late for work.
exercises.example_sentence: She is usually late for work because of the traffic.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: they often play football on Sundays
exercises.example_sentence: They often play football on Sundays at the park.

exercises.question: Match the percentage to the adverb.
exercises.example_sentence: I always brush my teeth, but I never smoke.

exercises.question: Repeat: I sometimes go to the cinema.
exercises.answer: I sometimes go to the cinema.
exercises.example_sentence: I sometimes go to the cinema with my best friend.

exercises.question: He ___ goes to gym; he is very fit.
exercises.example_sentence: He usually goes to the gym; he is very fit.

exercises.question: Where does 'always' go? 'We ___ eat breakfast.'
exercises.example_sentence: We always eat breakfast before going to school.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: she is always happy in the morning
exercises.example_sentence: She is always happy in the morning.

exercises.question: Match the adverb to its opposite.
exercises.example_sentence: I always wake up early, but my brother never does.

exercises.question: Repeat: Do you often travel for work?
exercises.answer: Do you often travel for work?
exercises.example_sentence: Do you often travel for work or just for fun?

exercises.question: Russia is the ___ country in the world.
exercises.example_sentence: Russia is the largest country in the world by land area.

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct?
options: This book is more better than the last one.
This book is better than the last one.
This book is gooder than the last one.
exercises.answer: This book is better than the last one.
exercises.example_sentence: This book is better than the last one I read.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: Mount Everest is the highest mountain
exercises.example_sentence: Mount Everest is the highest mountain in the world.

exercises.question: Match the adjective to its superlative form.
exercises.example_sentence: That was the best meal and this is the worst weather.

exercises.question: Repeat: She is the most intelligent student.
exercises.answer: She is the most intelligent student.
exercises.example_sentence: She is the most intelligent student in our class.

exercises.question: Health is ___ important than money.
exercises.example_sentence: Health is more important than money.

exercises.question: Choose the correct superlative for 'heavy':
exercises.example_sentence: This suitcase is the heaviest one in the car.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: the bus is cheaper than the train
exercises.example_sentence: The bus is cheaper than the train.

exercises.question: Match the comparative to the superlative.
exercises.example_sentence: Today is hotter, but yesterday was the hottest day.

exercises.question: Repeat: This is the most expensive car.
exercises.answer: This is the most expensive car.
exercises.example_sentence: This is the most expensive car in the showroom.

exercises.question: Have you ever ___ to Paris?
exercises.example_sentence: Have you ever been to Paris during the summer?

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct?
options: I have never saw a whale.
I have never seen a whale.
I never have see a whale.
exercises.answer: I have never seen a whale.
exercises.example_sentence: I have never seen a whale in the wild.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: She has never eaten sushi before.

exercises.question: Match the verb to its past participle.
exercises.example_sentence: I have written the report and I am done.

exercises.question: Repeat: Have you ever traveled by boat?
exercises.answer: Have you ever traveled by boat?
exercises.example_sentence: Have you ever traveled by boat across the ocean?

exercises.question: We ___ finished our homework already.
exercises.example_sentence: We have finished our homework already.

exercises.question: Choose the correct question form:
exercises.example_sentence: Has he ever played golf on a professional course?

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: they have never met a famous person
exercises.example_sentence: They have never met a famous person in real life.

exercises.question: Match the infinitive to the participle.
exercises.example_sentence: I have read that book and bought a new one.

exercises.question: Repeat: I have never been so happy.
exercises.answer: I have never been so happy.
exercises.example_sentence: I have never been so happy in my entire life.

exercises.question: A chef is a person ___ cooks food in a restaurant.
exercises.example_sentence: A chef is a person who cooks food in a restaurant.

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct for an object?
options: This is the car who I bought.
This is the car which I bought.
This is the car where I bought.
exercises.answer: This is the car which I bought.
exercises.example_sentence: This is the car which I bought last week.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: I know the woman who lives there
exercises.example_sentence: I know the woman who lives there.

exercises.question: Match the noun to the relative pronoun.
exercises.example_sentence: The teacher who helped me and the laptop which I used.

exercises.question: Repeat: The book that I'm reading is great.
exercises.answer: The book that I'm reading is great.
exercises.example_sentence: The book that I'm reading is great for learning English.

exercises.question: I have a friend ___ speaks four languages.
exercises.example_sentence: I have a friend who speaks four languages fluently.

exercises.question: Choose the correct relative pronoun for 'film':
options: The film who we saw was long.
The film which we saw was long.
The film where we saw was long.
exercises.answer: The film which we saw was long.
exercises.example_sentence: The film which we saw last night was very long.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: this is the house that he built
exercises.example_sentence: This is the house that he built for his family.

exercises.question: Match the beginning to the ending.
exercises.example_sentence: He is the boy who won the race yesterday.

exercises.question: Repeat: Is he the man who called you?
exercises.answer: Is he the man who called you?
exercises.example_sentence: Is he the man who called you this morning?

exercises.question: I went to the supermarket ___ some milk.
exercises.hint: Use 'to' + base verb to show purpose.
exercises.example_sentence: I went to the supermarket to buy some milk and eggs.

exercises.question: Which sentence explains a reason correctly?
options: She is studying hard for pass the exam.
She is studying hard to pass the exam.
She is studying hard to passing the exam.
exercises.answer: She is studying hard to pass the exam.
exercises.example_sentence: She is studying hard to pass the exam next week.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: I called to wish you a happy birthday
exercises.example_sentence: I called to wish you a happy birthday!

exercises.question: Match the action to its purpose.
exercises.hint: Match the object to its function.
exercises.example_sentence: I use a camera to take photos of my family.

exercises.question: Repeat: He moved to London to find a job.
exercises.answer: He moved to London to find a job.
exercises.example_sentence: He moved to London to find a job in finance.

exercises.question: They are saving money ___ a new house.
exercises.example_sentence: They are saving money to buy a new house in the country.

exercises.question: Choose the best response to 'Why did you go to the library?':
exercises.hint: Infinitives can start a short answer.
exercises.example_sentence: I went to the library to borrow a book for my project.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: he goes to the gym to stay fit
exercises.example_sentence: He goes to the gym to stay fit and healthy.

exercises.question: Match the place to the reason for going there.
exercises.example_sentence: I went to the bakery to buy bread this morning.

exercises.question: Repeat: I'm here to help you.
exercises.example_sentence: Don't worry, I'm here to help you with your work.

exercises.question: This isn't my coat. Is it ___?
exercises.example_sentence: This isn't my coat. Is it yours?

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct?
exercises.example_sentence: The red car is hers, but the blue one is mine.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: The big house is ours.

exercises.question: Match the person to the possessive pronoun.
exercises.example_sentence: This book is mine and those are theirs.

exercises.question: Repeat: These keys are mine.
exercises.example_sentence: These keys are mine, thank you for finding them.

exercises.question: The children have new toys. These toys are ___.
exercises.example_sentence: These toys are theirs, so please be careful.

exercises.question: Is that his phone? Yes, it is ___.
exercises.hint: 'His' is both an adjective and a pronoun.
exercises.example_sentence: Is that his phone? Yes, it is his.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: Whose bag is this? I think it's yours.

exercises.question: Match the ownership phrases.
exercises.example_sentence: It belongs to us, so it is ours.

exercises.question: Repeat: That's not yours, it's mine!
exercises.example_sentence: That's not yours, it's mine! Put it back.

exercises.question: I cut ___ while I was cooking dinner.
exercises.example_sentence: I cut myself while I was cooking dinner.

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct?
options: They enjoyed themselves at the party.
They enjoyed themself at the party.
They enjoyed theirselves at the party.
exercises.answer: They enjoyed themselves at the party.
exercises.example_sentence: They enjoyed themselves at the party last night.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: She painted the room herself without any help.

exercises.question: Match the subject to the reflexive pronoun.
exercises.example_sentence: We can do it ourselves, so you should do it yourself.

exercises.question: Repeat: He taught himself how to play piano.
exercises.answer: He taught himself how to play piano.
exercises.example_sentence: He taught himself how to play piano using videos.

exercises.question: Be careful with that knife! Don't hurt ___!
exercises.example_sentence: Be careful with that knife! Don't hurt yourself!

exercises.question: Choose the correct pronoun for a cat:
exercises.hint: Use the neutral reflexive for animals.
exercises.example_sentence: The cat cleaned itself after eating.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: you can fix the bike yourselves
exercises.example_sentence: You can fix the bike yourselves if you have the tools.

exercises.question: Match the sentence to the meaning.
exercises.example_sentence: I did it myself because I wanted to learn.

exercises.question: Repeat: We should take care of ourselves.
exercises.answer: We should take care of ourselves.
exercises.example_sentence: We should take care of ourselves during the winter.

exercises.question: I am ___ visit my grandparents this weekend.
exercises.example_sentence: I am going to visit my grandparents this weekend in the countryside.

exercises.question: Which sentence is a correct future plan?
options: She is going to buy a new car.
She going to buy a new car.
She is go to buy a new car.
exercises.answer: She is going to buy a new car.
exercises.example_sentence: She is going to buy a new car because her old one broke.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: what are you going to do tonight ?
exercises.hint: Question word + be + subject + going to...
exercises.example_sentence: What are you going to do tonight after work?

exercises.question: Match the person to the correct form of 'be going to'.
exercises.hint: Match the subject and the verb 'to be'.
exercises.example_sentence: They are going to travel, and he is going to stay home.

exercises.question: Repeat: It's going to rain soon.
exercises.example_sentence: Look at those dark clouds; it's going to rain soon.

exercises.question: We ___ not going to watch the game tonight.
exercises.example_sentence: We are not going to watch the game tonight because we are tired.

exercises.question: Choose the correct question:
options: Is he going to cook dinner?
Does he going to cook dinner?
Are he going to cook dinner?
exercises.answer: Is he going to cook dinner?
exercises.example_sentence: Is he going to cook dinner for us tonight?

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: I'm going to study French next year
exercises.example_sentence: I'm going to study French next year in Paris.

exercises.question: Match the intention to the situation.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm thirsty, so I'm going to drink water.

exercises.question: Repeat: Are you going to join us?
exercises.answer: Are you going to join us?
exercises.example_sentence: We are going to the cinema. Are you going to join us?
